definition:
An $n$-bit binary *Gray code* is a non-repeating sequence of the
integers from $0$ to $2^n-1$ inclusive such that the binary
representation of each number in the sequence differs by exactly one bit
from the binary representation of the previous number: that is, the
Hamming distance between consecutive elements is $1$. In addition, we
also define a *cyclic Gray code* to be a Gray code where an extra
condition is imposed: The last number in the sequence must differ by
exactly one bit from the first number in the sequence.

For example, one $3$-bit cyclic Gray code is:

$$000_2$$ $$010_2$$ $$011_2$$ $$001_2$$ $$101_2$$ $$111_2$$ $$110_2$$
$$100_2$$

There is a one-to-one correspondence between all possible $n$-bit Gray
codes and all possible Hamiltonian cycles on an $n$-dimensional
hypercube. (To see why this is so, imagine assigning a binary number to
each vertex of a hypercube where an edge joins each pair of vertices
that differ by exactly one bit.)
